author: sky.cactus
content: The thing that makes PoS actually work is the ability to after-the-fact punish.  If we are unwilling to do that, then I would argue we shouldn't switch to Proof of Stake.

author: sky.cactus
content: PoS without after-the-fact slashing is very dangerous IMO because a wealthy attacker can, without any infrastructure cost, only capital costs, takeover the network and censor/reorg freely.  At least with PoW the attacker has to have a bunch of hardware that will have reduced value if they burn down the network they mine.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are ways for individual nodes to detect censorship.  The difficulty is in coming to consensus on when to start ignoring block producers because of it.

author: killari.

author: sky.cactus
content: I designed a system for proof of benevolence for this.  It made the trade of liveness for censorship resistance.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially if your node detected censorship it would functionally halt, but continue to inform it's peers about the censorship.

author: sky.cactus
content: Not all nodes would halt on the same block, but they would all eventually halt (assuming no eclipse attack).

author: sky.cactus
content: Rebooting the system would require humans to decide where to restart from.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem is that not everyone witnesses censorship at the same time.

author: sky.cactus
content: So even if everyone agrees censorship happened, they can't all agree on *when* it happened, so coordinating how to proceed in a deterministic way is really hard.

author: 0xsadcat
content: There's one way to have censorship resistance at the cost of a higher cpu/gpu load. Each block contains a secret tx encrypted with a vdf. Each validator starts solving vdf. After 100 blocks the decrypted tx must be included (unless empty - then just the decrypted message that proves it)

author: 0xsadcat
content: The cost is having to solve 100 vdf in parallel

author: 0xsadcat
content: So really it would add a gpu requirement to each validator

author: jgm
content: What would stop a censoring proposer adding their own encrypted tx to the block?

author: 0xsadcat
content: The only real danger is from censoring blocks with unwanted transactions. This way as long as there's even one honest validator every tx gets included eventually

author: 0xsadcat
content: I suppose rather than 100 blocks it's better to require putting the tx from the last finalized slot with some additional delay

author: 0xsadcat
content: So it's simply impossible to censor unless the censoring entity has 2/3 and it's communicating - a whitelist of validators, rather than censoring some specific tx

author: 0xsadcat
content: Hmm. But let's say eth is 10k. One validator is $320k. Is a gpu requirement asking too much in return for censorship resistance?

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, you haven't made the case that it isn't possible without wasting energy. There's so much moon math out there, probably some weird zk-commit-reveal-threshold-signature-decryption option that doesn't require GPUs.

author: 0xsadcat
content:
The point of vdf is to require sequential computation that takes time
So you need n parallel sequential computations. Could also be cpu cores
I don't see how reveal schemes solve anything - how do you prevent censorship of the reveal? The whole point of vdf is that tx is already included in full, but the censoring party can't decode it before it's time to propose next block/etc

author: 0xsadcat
content: Or more generally. Anything that requires publishing new info afterwards is pointless. So vdf is literally the only solution to make censorship resistance have exact same security properties as liveness (ie. only whitelisting validators defeats it)

content: How can you poison the state to prevent people from eg. sending their eth?

author: 0xsadcat
content: If their balance is still high enough and nonce matches, the tx is correct

author: pietjepuk
content: If you only care about that very limited use case, then maybe. I was thinking about general transactions executing arbitrary code. I still think that e.g. threshold signing is a less wasteful solution, but again don't know enough about it.

author: 0xsadcat
content: The cases where the tx could be invalidated are a small minority. Eg. It's not really possible to prevent a dex sale without slippage

author: 0xsadcat
content:
No other scheme can work even theoretically with the 2/3 property. Defeating this requires 2/3+ of validators

Anything else at best needs a honest majority. Because if you need any future message, the block with it can be censored by a majority ignoring it during the proposal. Then one of censoring validators makes a normal correct block which is accepted by everyone. So the validator that tries to include it gets penalized for being offline
